Although selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3, CO catalytic oxidation, and selective catalytic reduction of NO x with CO have been used to control NO x and CO from mobile and industrial sources, the simultaneous removal of NO x and CO at low temperatures remains a great challenge due to the specificity of each catalytic reaction. Here, we achieve the simultaneous abatement of NO x and CO at low temperatures by skillfully utilizing a tandem catalyst system (e.g., Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 as oxidation-SCR tandem catalysts). Through a series of catalytic activity evaluations and structural characterizations, we report that NO can promote the oxidation of CO due to the easier decomposition of the intermediates formed by the combination of adsorbed NO species and gaseous CO, and the faster supply of O* required for CO oxidation in CO+O2+NO2/NO atmosphere. Meanwhile, the heat released from the oxidation of CO not only accelerates the oxidation of NO in the oxidation system, but also contributes to the high reaction rate of subsequent fast NH3-SCR. Eventually, 100 % conversion of CO and 80 % conversion of NO appear at 128 and 186 °C, respectively. This work provides a new strategy for the simultaneous and efficient removal of CO and NO x at lower temperatures. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Simultaneous abatement of NO x and CO Tandem catalyst system NH3-SCR Catalytic oxidation of CO Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) and carbon monoxide (CO) from sufficient/insufficient combustion of fuels (C + 0.5O2 → CO, C + CO2 → 2CO, R3N (nitrogenous organic matters) + O2 → NO + NO2 + CO2 + H2O) in mobile and industrial sources are two typical air pollutants, which are harmful to human health and environment [1]. The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) and catalytic oxidation of CO are the state-of-the-art technologies for NO x and CO removal, individually [2–4]. However, NO x and CO often coexist in practice, for example, in steel industry, it is known that the CO concentration in the coke oven flue gas is 2000–5000 mg/m3, the CO content of the sinter tail gas is as high as 10,000 mg/m3 [5], and the NO x concentration is generally in the range of 300–1500 mg/m3, so the simultaneous removal of CO and NO x should be widely concerned. One feasible technology for simultaneously removing CO and NO x is to use CO as reductant to directly react with NO x to generate N2 and CO2, i.e., CO-SCR (2CO + 2NO → 2CO2 + N2, 2NO2 + 4CO → N2 + 4CO2) [6,7]. The supported noble metal catalysts have been widely used for NO x and CO control in automobile exhaust through CO-SCR [8,9]. However, the continued use of precious metal catalysts in the large-scale steel and coking industries is extremely difficult due largely to the high cost of catalysts and the low flue temperatures. Although transition metal oxide catalysts have been developed to attempt to solve this issue, the actual presence of O2 severely inhibits its application because O2 is more competitive than NO for CO [10,11]. Another attempt has also been made to achieve both CO catalytic oxidation and NH3-SCR reactions on the same catalyst, but it is undesirable because of the poor selectivity of N2 [12,13]. Therefore, the development of a transition metal oxide catalyst that can simultaneously control NO x and CO emissions from the low-temperature steel and coking industrial stack gasses remains challenging. Motivated by a pre-sco process and the exhaust-controlling technology used in diesel engines [14,15], an appealing alternative is to develop a tandem catalyst system (Fig. 1 ), in which catalytic oxidation of CO and NH3-SCR occur sequentially. Such a tandem catalyst system should consist of two kinds of catalysts, CO oxidation catalyst and NH3-SCR catalyst. Apart from the CO oxidation, the oxidizing catalyst is also expected to quantitatively oxidize NO to NO2, enabling a fast SCR reaction (NO + NO2 + 2NH3 → 2N2 + 3H2O) to occur over the subsequent NH3-SCR catalyst [16,17]. Meanwhile, it is reported that NO molecules can accelerate the reaction rate of CO oxidation via providing active oxygen species (O*) and NO2 oxidant, as described by three reactions: NO + O2 → NO2 + O*; CO + O* → CO2; CO + NO2 → CO2 + NO [18–20]. Hence, we define a concept, “reactant-promoting effect”, to describe the reactivity enhancement of the tandem catalyst system. The CO oxidation in the presence of O2 is typically the exothermic reaction with an enthalpy of ∼ 283.5 kJ/mol [21], which can often occur in a relatively low temperature range (T < 200 °C) even over transition metal oxide catalysts [4], but the relatively high temperatures (T > 200 °C) are required for the NO oxidation and SCR, and extra energy inputs are often required in order to keep the high reaction rates [22,23]. The oxidation-SCR catalyst system can effectively utilize the energy released from the CO oxidation not only to accelerate the NO oxidation over CO oxidation catalyst [24], but also to accelerate the NO reduction over the subsequent fast SCR system by heating the stack gas. Likewise, we define another concept, “energy-promoting effect” to describe the activity improvement of the oxidation-SCR tandem catalyst system. In consequence, it is feasible to simultaneously abate NO and CO at the low temperatures on transition metal oxide catalysts with the oxidation-SCR tandem mode via combining the reactant- and energy- co-promoting effects. In this work, a tandem catalyst system used for efficient synergistic removal of NO x and CO is designed. A Cu1/MnO2 catalyst with excellent oxidation property and a Ce-W/TiO2 catalyst with high NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity are selected to be the oxidation catalyst and NH3-SCR catalyst in the tandem system, respectively. These catalysts have been reported in detail in our previous studies [23,25]. A series of comparative experiments combined with in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) reveal the mechanism of simultaneous removal of NO x and CO over the tandem catalyst system via reactant- and energy- co-promoting effects. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 were synthesized via a solid-phase reaction and a successive impregnation method, individually, as detailed in our previous studies [23,25]. V-W/TiO2 was prepared by an impregnation method. Firstly, 10 g TiO2 powers were added into 40 mL deionized water and stirred for 10 min to obtain a turbid solution. Secondly, the operation of sequentially adding appropriate amount substances to the above turbid solution and stirring for 10 min was performed, and the substances added were VOSO4, (NH4)6H2W12O40, polyethylene oxide (PEO) and methyl cellulose (MC) in order. Thirdly, the pH was adjusted to 7 by adding aqueous ammonia to the final suspension. Fourthly, the obtained neutral slurry was heated and evaporated to dryness in a water bath at 80 °C. After drying at room temperature for 12 h, the dried solids were calcined sequentially at 250 °C for 2 h and 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 2°C min−1 to get V-W/TiO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectra were acquired by using a Nicolet iS 50 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer equipped with a Harrick Scientific DRIFT cell and a mercury-cadmium-telluride MCT/A detector. The spectra were collected by accumulating 64 scans at a 4 cm−1 resolution in the wavenumber range of 1000–4000 cm−1. Before each test, the catalysts diluted 50 times with KBr were pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in a flow of 80 vol.% N2 + 20 vol.% O2 (150 mL min−1). After the catalysts were cooled to 50 °C under the same atmosphere as the pretreatment, the background spectra were collected. The DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption were obtained after exposing the catalysts to a flow of 1 vol.% CO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h. The DRIFT spectra of CO + NO + O2 co-adsorption were obtained after exposing the catalysts to a flow of 5000/500 ppm CO + 5000/500 ppm NO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h. The DRIFT spectra of CO + NO, NO2+CO, NO2+CO+O2 co-adsorption were obtained after exposing the catalysts to a flow of 500 ppm CO + 500 ppm NO/NO2 + 5.5 vol.% O2 (if included) /N2 (50 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h. For the reaction of pre-adsorbed CO + O2 with NO, the catalyst was exposed to 1 vol.% CO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h, then the DRIFT spectra were collected in a flow of 1 vol.% CO + 1 vol.% NO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) over time. For the reaction of pre-adsorbed NO + O2 with CO, the catalyst was exposed to a flow of 1 vol.% NO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h. After purging physically adsorbed NO x by a flow of N2 (50 mL min−1) for 1 h, the DRIFT spectra were collected in a flow of 1 vol.% CO + 5.5 vol.% O2 /N2 (50 mL min−1) over time. All DRIFT spectra were collected by deducting the background spectra under the corresponding conditions. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The elimination performance of the catalysts for NO and CO was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor. The reaction conditions of CO oxidation were set as follows: 0.2 g catalysts were used, the total flow rate was 1000 mL min−1, including 500 ppm CO, 5.5 vol% O2, and N2 as the balance gas. The reaction conditions of standard NH3-SCR were set as follows: 0.2 g catalysts were used, the total flow rate was 1000 mL min−1, including 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 3 vol% O2, and N2 as the balance gas. For the reaction of CO + NO, CO + NO + O2 and CO + NO2 + O2, 0.2 g catalysts were used, the feed gas (1000 mL min−1) contained 500 ppm CO, 500 ppm NO/NO2, 5.5 vol% O2 (if included), and N2 as the balance gas. In the tandem catalyst system, the flue gas (983.3 mL min−1) contained 500/1500 ppm CO, 500 ppm NO, 5.5 vol% O2, and N2 as the balance gas was first passed through an oxidation reactor loaded with 0.2/0.5 g catalysts at a specific temperature (220/190 °C), and then the tail gas (983.3 mL min−1) from the oxidation reactor together with 3 vol% NH3/N2 (16.7 min−1) was fed into a reduction reactor loaded with 0.2 g catalysts. The concentrations of NO, NO2, N2O, NH3, CO and CO2 were monitored by a FTIR spectrometer (ANTARIS IGS Analyzer, Thermo Fisher Scientific) and an on-line Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph equipped with the TCD and FID detectors. The X CO, X NO, and S N2 were defined as: X CO = C O in − C O out C O in × 100 % X NO = N O in − N O out N O in × 100 % S N 2 = N O in + N H 3 in − N O out − N H 3 out − N O 2 out − 2 N 2 O out N O in + N H 3 in − N O out − N H 3 out × 100 % where COin, NOin and NH3in represent the inlet concentrations of CO, NO and NH3, respectively, and COout, NOout, NH3out, NO2out, and N2Oout represent the outlet concentrations of CO, NO, NH3, NO2 and N2O, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of the tandem catalyst system for CO and NO x Cu1/MnO2 as a CO oxidation catalyst and Ce-W/TiO2 as an NH3-SCR catalyst were used to form a tandem catalyst system, and their catalytic performance for the removal of CO and NO individually were firstly tested. The CO conversions (X CO) over Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 as a function of temperature (T) in CO oxidation are shown in Fig. S1. Cu1/MnO2 with excellent oxidation property has a high removal efficiency of CO, and the X CO reaches 100 % at 148 °C. While the elimination of CO by Ce-W/TiO2 is poor, and the X CO is consistently zero throughout the test temperature interval. Similarly, Figs. S2 and S3 present the NO conversions (X NO) and N2 selectivity (S N2) over Ce-W/TiO2 and Cu1/MnO2 as a function of T in NH3-SCR. Ce-W/TiO2 exhibits high NH3-SCR reactivity and the X NO reaches up to 80 % at 274 °C. Ce-W/TiO2 is also highly selective to N2, no by-products of NO2 and N2O are produced during the whole reaction. For Cu1/MnO2, its excellent oxidation property makes it extremely unselective for N2 in NH3-SCR. In many cases, Cu1/MnO2 oxidizes NH3 to N2O and NO2. Considering that NO and CO can be removed simultaneously in the CO-SCR reaction, the catalytic performance of Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 in CO-SCR was also evaluated. As shown in Figs. S4 and S5, X NO of Cu1/MnO2 are unsatisfactory, reaching less than 80 % before 350 °C, and the consumption of CO is mainly for the reduction of Cu1/MnO2 rather than the conversion in CO-SCR. X CO and X NO of Ce-W/TiO2 in CO-SCR are negligible over the entire range of reaction temperatures because the concentrations of CO and NO remain nearly constant. Thus, neither Cu1/MnO2 nor Ce-W/TiO2 can achieve efficient simultaneous removal of CO and NO individually, and a tandem catalyst system consisting of them should be well investigated. The conversions of CO and NO over Cu1/MnO2 as a function of T in CONOO2 mixtures are shown in Fig. 2 (a and b). Both CO and NO are oxidized in Cu1/MnO2 oxidizing system. The oxidation of CO apparently occurs at relatively low temperatures, and CO is fully oxidized at 128 °C. The oxidation of NO begins at 80 °C, and the oxidation product of NO is only NO2, because the total concentrations of NO and NO2 remain constant at 500 ppm. At 220 °C, half of the NO is oxidized to NO2. It is well known that the degree of a fast NH3-SCR reaction will be maximized when NO and NO2 are kept at the same concentration in the flue gas [26], accompanied by the highest removal efficiency for NO x . Therefore, we set the temperature of the oxidizing system to 220 °C. The exhaust passing through this oxidizing system will contain 0 ppm CO, 500 ppm CO2, 250 ppm NO and 250 ppm NO2. Then the tail gas from the oxidizing system is introduced into the NH3-SCR reaction system to react with NH3, and the concentrations of the tail gas from the oxidizing system and the mixture in the NH3-SCR system are shown in Fig. 2c. NO2 react with NH3 quickly to form NH4NO3 (NO2 + 2NH3 → NH4NO3 + 2N2 + H2O) [27], reducing the concentration of NO x to ∼ 280 ppm rapidly. When the NH3-SCR reaction system where Ce-W/TiO2 is located warmed up, the deposition of NH4NO3 slows down, leading to a gradual increase in the concentrations of NO2 and NH3 with increasing temperature. At 160 °C, the outlet concentration of NO x is consistent with the inlet concentration of NO x , and the drop of NH3 and NO x starts to occur, so it can be inferred that the deposition of NH4NO3 is present until 160 °C, and before 160 °C, the NH3-SCR reaction system contains NO, NO2 and NH3 not involved in the deposition of NH4NO3, and undecomposed NH4NO3. Between 130 °C and 160 °C, the concentration of NO decreased with a corresponding increase in NO2 compared to the initial value (250 ppm), probably due to the occurrence of reaction (1) between NH4NO3 and NO [26,28,29]. After 160 °C, the simultaneous decrease in NO, NO2, and NH3 concentrations is due to the rapid SCR (reaction (2)) that occurs. Obviously, the sum of reaction (1) and reaction (2) gives reaction (3). It has been demonstrated that a superior NO conversion efficiency can be achieved by means of an enhanced SCR reaction involving selective reduction of NO to N2 by NH3 and ammonium nitrate (reaction (3))[30,31]. Therefore, in this study, NH4NO3 is not simply decomposed but undergoes an enhanced SCR reaction (reaction (3)), and the superior NO conversion efficiency is mainly derived from the fast SCR reaction involving NH4NO3. X CO of the tandem catalyst system is much higher due to the presence of NO, reaching 100 % at 128 °C. Whereas the temperature required for 100 % X CO is 148 °C for Cu1/MnO2 in CO+O2 reaction without NO. X CO never reaches 100 % in CO-SCR reactions for both Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 within the tested temperature range (Figs. S4 and S5). As expected, the tandem catalyst system also shows the highest catalytic activity for NO due to the energy-promoting effect and fast NH3-SCR reaction. The X NO reaches up to 80 % at 186 °C, while the temperature required for 80 % XNO over Ce-W/TiO2 is about 274 °C, which is delayed by 88 °C compared to the tandem catalyst system. X NO never reaches 80 % in CO-SCR reactions for both Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 within the tested temperature range (Figs. S4 and S5). Thus, the oxidation-SCR tandem system via combining the reactant- and energy- co-promoting effects can simultaneously abate NO and CO at the low temperatures. 3.2 The facilitation of CO removal by reactant-promoting effect The facilitation of CO removal by reactant-promoting effect is mainly reflected in the fact that the oxidation of CO is promoted due to the presence of NO (Figs. 3a and S6a). To reveal the facilitation mechanism of NO on CO oxidation, a series of DRIFT spectra of Cu1/MnO2 in different gas atmospheres were collected. As shown in Figs. 4 a and S7a, in the CO+O2 atmosphere, with time, the bands located at ∼ 2172, 2113, 1632, 1543, 1415, 1318, 1159, 1112 and 1046 cm−1 are observed. The bands at 2172 and 2113 cm−1 are assigned to gaseous and physical adsorbed CO [32], the bands at 1632 and 1415 cm−1 are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration peaks of HCO3 − [20], the band appearing at 1543 cm−1 pertains to asymmetric stretching vibration of COO− [33], the bands at 1318 and 1159 cm−1 correspond to stretching vibration of bidentate carbonate and bridge carbonate, respectively [20]. The bands of carbonate and inorganic carboxylate appear at 1112 and 1046 cm−1, respectively [20,34,35]. After the introduction of NO, the peaks attributed to COO−, HCO3 − and CO3 2− disappeared rapidly within 1 min and the new peaks associated with NO appeared on the catalyst surface (Fig. S8), indicating the adsorbed CO species can be reacted with NO. However, when CO, O2 and NO were co-adsorbed on Cu1/MnO2, as shown in Figs. 4b and S7b, no peaks related to CO were found except for the peaks of gaseous CO appearing at 2172 and 2173 cm−1 [32], in contrast, the peaks attributed to NO+ at 2401 cm−1, gaseous NO at 1903, 1848 cm−1, N2O4 at 1766 cm−1, NO2 at 1631, 1602 cm−1, NO3 − at 1408, 1365 cm−1, and NO2 − at 1207 cm−1 grew stronger over time [20,36–41]. These results show that the adsorption of NO on Cu1/MnO2 is much stronger than CO, and CO is difficult to adsorb onto the catalyst surface in the presence of NO. Generally, the oxidation of CO over reducible metal oxides follows the Mars-van Krevelen (M-K) mechanism, where CO first adsorbs on the catalyst surface and reacts with the surface active oxygen [42]. Apparently, the presence of NO alters the path of CO oxidation, and it is likely that CO reacts in gaseous form with the NO-related species adsorbed on the catalyst surface in CO+O2+NO mixture. To further verify whether CO can react with the adsorbed NO species, we recorded in situ DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 pre-adsorbed Cu1/MnO2 in a flow of CO. As shown in Fig. 5 a, when Cu1/MnO2 was purged with N2 after NO+O2 adsorption (0 min), the characteristic peaks of gaseous NO at 1903, 1848 cm−1, and NO2 at 1631, 1602 cm−1 disappeared, and the peaks attributed to NO+, N2O4, nitrate, and nitrite substances were retained at 2400, 1766, 1393, 1353 cm−1 [20,36,38,40]. After the introduction of CO, in order to better visualize the change in NO-adsorbed species, the difference in intensity of the introduction of CO for t minute was obtained by subtracting the intensity of DRIFT spectrum before the introduction of CO (i.e. 0 min) from the intensity of DRIFT spectrum after the introduction of CO for t minute (Fig. 5b). The clear inverted peaks occur at 2400, 1766 and 1393 cm−1, the significant bulges attributed to gaseous CO at 2173, 2113 cm−1 [32], and gaseous NO2 at 1631, 1602 cm−1 are also appeared [36,41]. In addition, peaks such as a and b appear in Fig. 5b, which do not correspond to the peaks in the original spectra, the appearance of them is a response to the shift of the DRIFT spectra after the introduction of CO. Therefore, we conclude that CO can react with the adsorbed NO species, and it has also been reported that NO promotes CO oxidation by decomposing the intermediates, which are formed by combining nitrates and nitrites with gaseous CO [20]. From this, it can be easily deduced that CO reacts with adsorbed NO species at a higher rate than the conventional CO oxidation reaction in CO + O2 atmosphere, mainly due to the easier decomposition of the intermediates formed by the combination of adsorbed NO species and gaseous CO. 3.3 The role of NO2 and O* generated in CO+O2+NO The presence of NO2 in a CO + O2 + NO atmosphere is known (Fig. 4b), whether NO2 will react with CO, or whether NO2 can promote the oxidation of CO should be studied. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, NO is oxidized to NO2 at about 80 °C, at which point the X CO is ∼ 80 %, so the advance in CO ignition temperature is in no way due to NO2 from a macroscopic point of view. In an attempt to investigate the promotion of CO oxidation by NO2 generated in CO+O2+NO atmosphere, we compared the oxidation of CO in CO+NO+O2, CO+NO2+O2, CO+O2, CO+NO2 and CO+NO atmospheres. Figs. 6 a and S9 show the X CO in different reaction atmospheres over Cu1/MnO2 as a function of T. The X CO increases significantly with the introduction of NO2 to CO+O2. However, in CO+NO+O2, when CO is fully oxidized, the amount of NO2 produced is still very low, less than 50 ppm (Fig. 2a and b), and the oxidation of CO remains almost the same when the concentration of NO2 is increased to 500 and 1000 ppm (Fig. S9a), suggesting that the enhancement of CO oxidation is not related to the concentration of NO2 or NO2 itself. It has to be mentioned that the X CO in CO+O2 system is significantly higher than that in CO+NO system and CO+NO2 system. It shows the role of O2 in CO oxidation is much greater than that of NO2 and NO. The difference of X CO in the NO+O2+CO and NO2+O2+CO systems is not significant (Fig. S9b), so it can be deduced that the promotion of CO oxidation in CO+O2+NO atmosphere does not come from NO2 and NO itself, but is related to the reaction of NO2/NO and O2, i.e., CO is best oxidized when O2 and NO/NO2 are coexisting. In CO+NO/NO2+O2 systems, the following cycle of reactions will occur, NO + O2 → NO2 + O*; CO + O* → CO2; CO + NO2 → CO2 + NO, which produces O*, and thus O* may be the key to the promotion of CO oxidation. To clarify the importance of O*, we further parsed the reaction of CO + NO without O2. As shown in Fig. 6b, in CO+NO atmosphere, CO first reacts with the O* on catalyst surface until O* is consumed at 225 °C, accompanied by the formation of an equivalent amount of CO2. Then, since there is no O2 to replenish the consumed O* timely, in the temperature interval of 225–325 °C, NO as a substitute oxide undergoes the following redox reactions with CO to produce N2 and N2O: CO + 2NO → CO2 + N2O, 2CO + 2NO → 2CO2 + N2, and above 325 °C, the reaction between NO and CO is dominated by 2CO + 2NO → 2CO2 + N2. Obviously, the timely supply of oxides is important in the process of CO oxidation, and the type of oxides determines the rate of the reaction and the oxidation products of CO. For the oxidation of CO + O2, we preferred supply is O*. Compared to the activation of O2 that produces O* in CO+O2, the supply of O* is more rapid in CO+O2+NO/NO2 mixtures due to the presence of NO + O2 → NO2 + O* reaction, which is perhaps another reason for the promotion of CO oxidation by NO. 3.4 The facilitation of NO removal by energy-promoting effect and fast NH3-SCR Another feature of the oxidation-SCR tandem system is that NO removal can be facilitated by energy-promoting effect and fast NH3-SCR. The reaction of CO oxidation is a typical exothermic reaction with an enthalpy of 283.5 kJ/mol. For a gas containing 2000 ppm CO per unit volume, the heat given off by the complete reaction of CO is about 25.31 kJ, which is calculated by the following equation: 283.15 kJ/mol × (2000 × 10−6 × 103 / 22.4) mol ≈ 25.31 kJ, where 22.4 is the molar volume of gas in mol/L. Since air makes up the majority of the flue gas, the increase in flue gas temperature (ΔT) can be estimated to be 20 °C, calculated by dividing the heat by the specific heat capacity of the air (∼ 1.005 kJ/kg·K), and then by the density of air (1.29 kg/m3), using the following formula: ΔT ≈ 25.31 / 1.005 / 1.29 ≈ 20 °C. It has also been reported that the complete oxidation of 2000 ppm CO can increase the flue gas temperature by about 20 °C [43]. Unfortunately, we did not monitor the change in temperature in this study due to the limitation in insulation of the transmission pipeline. The increase in flue gas temperature will undoubtedly promote the oxidation of NO to NO2. Fig. 7 a presents the X NO in the NO oxidation reaction with and without CO as a function of T. The promotion of NO oxidation by CO is also clearly seen. At 200 °C, the X NO is 30 % in the reaction of NO+O2, while it increases to ∼37 and ∼63 % in the presence of 500 ppm CO and 1500 ppm CO, respectively. If heat loss is not taken into account, logically, the energy released in the oxidation system will also be carried over to the subsequent NH3-SCR reaction system, thus giving a flue gas temperature in NH3-SCR system comparable to that of the oxidizing system. As mentioned earlier, due to the generation of NO2 in the oxidation system, a fast SCR reaction occurs within the NH3-SCR system, which is more sensitive to the temperature. As shown in Figs. 7b, S2a and S6b, increasing the flue gas temperature from 180 to 200 °C results in an 8.5 % increase in X NO from ∼8 to 16.5 % for standard NH3-SCR with Ce-W/TiO2 as the catalyst, and a 29.5 % increase in X NO from ∼63 to 92.5 % for fast NH3-SCR. Obviously, 29.5 % is much larger than 8.5 %. Thus, we can conclude that the oxidation-SCR tandem system can effectively utilize the heat released from CO oxidation to increase the flue gas temperature, not only accelerate the oxidation of NO in the oxidation system, but also contribute to the high reaction rate in subsequent fast NH3-SCR. 3.5 The universality and optimization of the tandem catalyst system To further investigate the generalizability of this oxidation-SCR tandem system in simultaneous abatement of NO x and CO, we replaced the catalyst in NH3-SCR reaction system from Ce-W/TiO2 to a commercial V-W/TiO2, and the oxidation system was still set at 220 °C and with Cu1/MnO2 as the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the NH3-SCR performance of V-W/TiO2 is significantly higher than that of Ce-W/TiO2, for standard NH3-SCR, the temperature at which X NO reaches 80 % on V-W/TiO2 (274 °C) is 37 °C lower than that on Ce-W/TiO2 (237 °C). For Cu1/MnO2 oxidation- V-W/TiO2 SCR tandem system (Figs. 8a and S10), the consumption reaction of NH4NO3 also occurs in NH3-SCR system, same as Ce-W/TiO2 SCR system, but the temperatures at which the initiation reduction of NO x and the complete removal of NO x on V-W/TiO2 are 150 and 200 °C, respectively, which are both 10 °C earlier than that on Ce-W/TiO2. These results indicate that the oxidation-SCR tandem system is suitable for any other catalysts, and the more active the coupled SCR system is, the lower the temperature for complete NO x removal. In practical industrial applications, if the heat loss is ignored in oxidation-SCR tandem system, a possible scenario is that the flue gas temperature of the oxidation system should be slightly lower than that of the NH3-SCR system due to the heat released from CO oxidation. To rationalize the temperature in oxidation-SCR tandem system, we adjusted the actual amounts of Cu1/MnO2 (0.5 g) in oxidation system and V-W/TiO2 (0.2 g) in NH3-SCR system to 5:2. As shown in Fig. 8b (left), the temperature for the complete removal of 1500 ppm CO is ∼105 °C and the temperature at which NO and NO2 reach the same concentration is 190 °C. Therefore, we set the temperature of the oxidation system at 190 °C, the temperature for complete removal of NO will remain at ∼ 200 °C (Figs. 8b (right) and S11). This indicates that the removal rates of NO and CO can be adjusted by changing the amounts of catalysts in oxidation and SCR systems in practical applications. 4 Conclusions In conclusions, we developed an oxidation-SCR tandem catalyst system for the simultaneous and efficient removal of CO and NO x . Taking Cu1/MnO2 Ce-W/TiO2 tandem catalysts as an example, with a series of comparative activity tests and DRIFTS, we found that the oxidation of CO can be promoted due to the presence of NO. The promotion of CO oxidation by NO can be due to the fact that the intermediates formed by the combination of adsorbed NO species and gaseous CO are more readily decomposed on the one hand, and on the other hand, the supply of O* required for CO oxidation is more rapid in CO+O2+NO2/NO atmosphere due to the presence of the NO + O2→NO2 +O * reaction. Meanwhile, the heat released from the complete reaction of 2000 ppm CO is estimated about 25.31 kJ, which increases the flue gas temperature by ∼20 °C. This heat not only accelerates the oxidation of NO in the oxidation system, but also contributes to the high reaction rate in subsequent fast NH3-SCR. Eventually, the complete conversion of CO and 80 % conversion of NO at 128 and 186 °C were achieved, respectively. In addition, we also confirmed the universality and optimizability of tandem catalyst systems by adjusting the type and amounts of catalysts in oxidation and SCR systems. This work may provide a new strategy for simultaneous and efficient removal of CO and NO x at lower temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Although selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3, CO catalytic oxidation, and selective catalytic reduction of NO x with CO have been used to control NO x and CO from mobile and industrial sources, the simultaneous removal of NO x and CO at low temperatures remains a great challenge due to the specificity of each catalytic reaction. Here, we achieve the simultaneous abatement of NO x and CO at low temperatures by skillfully utilizing a tandem catalyst system (e.g., Cu1/MnO2 and Ce-W/TiO2 as oxidation-SCR tandem catalysts). Through a series of catalytic activity evaluations and structural characterizations, we report that NO can promote the oxidation of CO due to the easier decomposition of the intermediates formed by the combination of adsorbed NO species and gaseous CO, and the faster supply of O* required for CO oxidation in CO+O2+NO2/NO atmosphere. Meanwhile, the heat released from the oxidation of CO not only accelerates the oxidation of NO in the oxidation system, but also contributes to the high reaction rate of subsequent fast NH3-SCR. Eventually, 100 % conversion of CO and 80 % conversion of NO appear at 128 and 186 °C, respectively. This work provides a new strategy for the simultaneous and efficient removal of CO and NO x at lower temperatures.
